newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: Clear NZ suggests treble damages for Act breaches.
newsitem.headline: Clear NZ suggests treble damages for Act breaches.

text.p: Abuse of monopoly power could be curbed by the risk of treble damages for breaches of the Commerce Act, Clear Communications chief executive Andrew Makin said on Wednesday.
Speaking at the Wellington Chamber of Commerce, Makin said the existing regulatory environment was not capable of achieving full competition in telecommunications unless it was adjusted.
"At the moment, light-handed regulation is simply another name for no regulation," he said.

Makin said the telecommunications industry did not need a regulator and government intervention did not need to be highly prescriptive. However, the government had a responsibility to provide an appropriate framework.
"And the framework in New Zealand at the moment is not appropriate -- if the recent experience hasn't taught us that, then it hasn't taught us anything," he said.

Specifically, Makin said, revisions to New Zealand's current regulatory model in the telecommunications industry required an effective statement of the legal principles on which interconnection was to be sought and given.
Makin said the resolution last year of Clear's long-standing dispute with Telecom over local service interconnection did not imply New Zealand's light-handed regulation was working.
He said compensatory damages for breaches of section 36 of the Commerce Act, which deals with monopolist abuse of a dominant position, did not go far enough.
Private plaintiffs and the Commerce Commission were unlikely to have the resources to challenge a violation once it was detected, he said.
Makin noted the observation of an American antitrust commentator that not all violations were detected, so single damages rules made violations profitable.

"Therefore, treble damages, which are not a peculiarly American phenomenon, but which date from the English Statute of Monopolies in 1623, would be a useful tool in New Zealand competition law," Makin said.
He added that the introduction of treble damages could have positive ramifications beyond competition law.

"Treble damages, by making companies and directors more accountable and hence more likely to consider the legality of proposed actions, would be one mechanism that could help create a more professional and sophisticated environment in New Zealand similar to comparable countries," he said.
Makin said the barriers to effective competition were greater in New Zealand than in the U.S., due to the small size of the economy and New Zealand's geographic isolation.
